Topic.Title: put options are getting expensive

Message.Msg: what does it mean ?

Topic.Title: put options are getting expensive

Message.Msg: i guess it means that option speculators believe that if bad news is released the shares would drop significantly more than they would go up, if good news was reported.

Topic.Title: put options are getting expensive

Message.Msg: $250 put is $34 away while $310 call is $26 away, so just based on dollar basis the put is $2 closer. However an equal difference form stock price always makes the puts a larger percent differential than the call, therefore puts will carry a bit more premium. As you get closer to earnings you might see the value of the same strike actually rise. Option sellers make money no matter what, except if your options call was correct by the differential and premium and direction. For example if you buy the $300 calls exp this week for $6, you will only make money if the stock goes to $306 plus by the time options expire. If stock goes down, stays unchanged or even goes up but not over $306, you lose money. So as you can see, you can be right that Amazon will rise and if Amazon only rises $15 which is significant by itself, you still lose money. This is why playing options before earnings is very risky, even if you call the direction correct. Almost all premium will be sucked out of options the day after earnings. AMZN seems to be carrying a 7-8% implied volatility which is very high.

Topic.Title: put options are getting expensive

Message.Msg: maybe it means they are gonna pull the rug on put buyers like they do most time in buying AMZN puts. Afterall, it's the put sellers who have made huge gobs of money selling put options as the prices rise in them and the demand is high: when do put buyers in AMZN ever make any money? maybe when the demand for them was low and prices low. So there's less for the sellers lever on. Just a thought.

Earnings themselves won't matter only top line growth and let me take the first part back, the way it goes with this stock bottom line results will only matter if they are strong and then of course they will give a wide range of guidance and the analysts won't hold their feet to the fire. As someone who favors fundamentals much more so than technicals I never understood why this stock gets such a rich valuation but the fact is those that have bet long here (not me!) have done very well. At some point they won't but when that will be is the million dollar question.

Topic.Title: EPS of 8 pennies. p/e of 3,900. A POS but the thieves luv it!

Message.Msg: You hit another topic that gets my nerve. The fact of high tech compensating people with options. Then they conveniently exclude stock based compensation from their earnings and call them adjusted earnings. GAAP is GAAP baby. When companies overly rely on this compensation you really need to figure it back and look at earnings with those adjustments back in. Not only that but stockholders get screwed with all the dilution. Even when companies have these grandiose buybacks they don't even buy enough back to offset the stock dilution. I can name only couple companies out of all the companies out there that actually buy back enough to reduce float vs stock option issuance. And then buybacks are normally done when the shares are grossly overpriced. On the free cash flow topic they can continue generating cash off of the a/p balance as long as sales grow and they drag out payments to vendors. It is a one time thing in the sense it makes a contribution the day that program starts. Then it gets to where there is no add back to operating cash flow when sales stagnate. Then it reverses and causes negative effects when the program that created the big a/p ends. When we ended our relationship with our vendor we had a relationship with that caused the big working capital adjustment it reversed big in that qtr that the program ended. With AMZN it won't really reverse unless they were to close their doors. They will always exploit that cashflow from vendors. It eventually gets to looking at current assets vs current liabilities excluding short term maturity of debt. Need to be at 1+. AMZN just has enough cash plus receivables plus inventory to cover a/p. If they were doing well the current ratio should be well above 1. The fact it is where it is at shows how this scheme has helped them. They could have a much lower ap balance but also a much lower cash balance. Conclusion is we both agree this is a scam. Bezos has always schemed to exploit any advantage he can get.

Topic.Title: DISGUSTING

I'm waiting for earnings to sell, if it spikes I'll sell some, if it dives I'll watch it and buy when it looks like its at a bottom. Now is the time to sell, if you haven't already. It's not the time to buy. The time to buy is when it dips 20%, which would be $230. AMZN always hits new all-time highs, so if you buy at $230, you can be assured it will go up to $285 again.

Message.Title: Very Important Facts About Amazon and LivingSocial
Message.Msg: I have read several messages about how fast LivingSocial is growing and the potential it has for Amazon. I am amazed at the stupidity of retail longs. First, you need to understand that LivingSocial is not part of Amazon! LivingSocial is its own (non-public) company. Amazon has only a 29% investment in LivingSocial (minority stake). Secondly, LivingSocial has operating losses of $753 million in the first 9 months of 2012! If they continue to lose at the same rate for the final quarter of 2012, LivingSocial will have operating losses of over $1 billion for the entire year! That is an incredible amount of money to lose . I don't understand how anyone could possibly get excited over any company that loses that kind of money, all of which has been funded by venture capitalists and Amazon (be aware that since Amazon has only a minority stake they don't show these losses on their income statement).

Message.Msg: Good point about Hurrican Sandy. The only argument against it would be the notion of catch-up transactions or goods replacement later in the quarter, whatever that may be. I was stuck in Lower Manhattan for Sandy week while there for a work trip, I can say first hand that there was almost no commerce taking place other than repairs and food. This really is a game of inches with AMZN with their tight, unforgiving margins, so this does matter.

Message.Title: the zoomed
Message.Msg: The zoom thing loses money on most on line sales. It's best selling product is a loss leader. It is in direct competition with SAP/IBM/ORCL/MSFT and a whole host of smaller players for the cloud. They keep dropping prices due to the competitors are getting better at the game. They spend on some new project announcement daily which never seems to get to the bottom line. Insiders have been selling with wicked speed. States are starting to tax. Profits have been falling for years. The more they sell the more they lose. Shipping costs are going up and we are entering the weak spring period. Spending on warehouses never ends and id they want to be big overseas they haven't even started to figure out how to get the goods there without adding ware houses to the moon. PE is currently 3000 plus. Stock is overly owned by institutions and has a very low short interest. SOUNDS GREAT TO ME
